segments.text: Summer had already stood at the door, bringing with it hot and long days, and she left the study table behind, bid farewell to her trips to Tel Aviv, the room she shared with her parents' friends, daughter during the middle of the week, and returned to Ashkelon to her pink house.
She had kept her promise, and even though she skipped seventh grade, she managed to finish high school.
And now, she was equal among all her peers, those old ones, most of whom had disappeared in the past two years, and the few new ones she encountered who learned to respect her depth.
On the last day of school, Avrache, the class educator, took them to the schoolyard and took a group photo of the class.
Afterward, he placed her next to the nearby utility pole and photographed her alone.
On the day they received their high school diplomas in an emotional ceremony, she found the two photos attached to the diploma.
Noticing her solo photo and knowing she looked a bit sad, a long-haired girl whose hair partly covered her face, leaning against the utility pole with a deep and inexplicable expression on her face.
Only then did she turn it over and saw the handwritten note, just a pole and a pillar.
It took a second and immediately tears welled in her eyes.
It never occurred to her that this is what he saw in her, and for the first time she wondered what others who crossed her path saw.
From the moment she returned home, she managed the pink hotel almost alone for entire days.
She took care of its cleanliness for its few regular residents and at the same time was somewhat raising herself, cooking, washing her clothes, entering into an almost blessed daily routine.
And in a strange way, she was calm with no fear.
This house was her fortress.
But that day, the moment the door swung open and he stood in the doorway, she knew immediately she was in trouble.
It didn't take much to understand.
Something in his sunken eyes, in his thin, tight lips, and in his skin color between gray and rust broadcasted some mental illness.
Within a second she felt uncontrolled fear and coldness spreading through her limbs.
She tried to recover and give her voice a casual tone, wanting to tell him it was closed so he'd leave.
But instead only a question came out of her mouth.
Hello, can I help you?
He stared at her with his sunken eyes, scanning her entire body and returning to her eyes.
Can I get a gold star beer?
he asked, after a long, oppressive silence.
She was stunned.
From that strange, sickly, ageless person came a deep, almost soothing voice, only to rise to a strange soprano tone at the end of the sentence, as if losing control.
She slowly stepped behind the bar, grateful in her heart for the barrier between them.
She pulled out a beer bottle and placed it on the counter next to a large glass.
She didn't pour the beer for him, as was her habit, standing still without trying to roll out a conversation.
Silent, almost waiting in silence for disaster to strike.
Are you completely alone here?
He suddenly broke the silence.
Here it comes, she fought, feeling the anxiety trembling back in her limbs.
No, she lied.
Her voice not entirely steady.
The residents will be here for dinner soon, and my dad is here too.
She hoped she was the only one who heard the tremor in her voice.
Knowing no one was there, and the only one who might surprise and arrive was Danny the Doctor, and maybe, just maybe, Yosuke from the semi-trailer as well.
She prayed in her heart they would walk in.
Okay, because it seems like you're completely alone here, he noted.
and again his tone rose at the end of the sentence, becoming soprano and uncontrolled.
She looked at him out of the corner of her eye, pretending to wipe glasses left to dry on a towel beside the counter.
From the side, he suddenly seemed pathetic and pitiable and a bit less threatening.
Who knows what's going on in his head?
He seemed completely unhinged and strange.
For a moment, she turned her back to him to place the glasses on the shelf across.
And within a second, she found him standing next to her, pressing his body against hers and a sharp sour smell of sweat rose to.
Her nostrils, she tried to push him away from her, but the bar, which had just been a barrier, suddenly turned into a trap from which there was no escape.

He shoved her to its end, and she felt the wooden boards pressing against her back, losing control and beginning to thrash like a wounded animal, hitting him with her arms and trying with all her might to push him off her.
His eyes turned completely wild, and in a fit of rage, he landed a terrible blow to her face and screamed, Stop!
Stop!
For a moment, she lost her balance.
One hand grasped the edge of the bar,
her head ringing with a thousand tones, and her vision blurred.
She clung to the frame of the bar with her claws, knowing she should under no circumstances lose consciousness.
He tried to tear her pants off, and in her heart, she thanked these jeans given to her by Carmella the neighbor from the packages she received from America.
which zipped on the side rather than the front like everyone else's and it confused him.
He raged in frustration and she heard her shirt sleeve tearing.
Now he pressed his entire body against hers and began to grind against her, his eyes rolling and he mumbled indistinct words.
Again and again, she tried to push him off her, hearing the grunts of effort coming from her throat, not believing this skinny guy had such strength, but then in one moment.
She glimpsed from the corner of her eye the whiskey bottle on the shelf next to her, managed to reach out and grab it, and just as she gathered all her strength, she smashed it over his head.
He collapsed to his knees, and in slow motion, his limbs sprawled across the bar floor.
A sharp smell of whiskey pierced her nose, freeing her from the sour scent of his sweat and bringing air back into her lungs.
She stood over him, frozen and trembling, still clutching the neck of the bottle that remained clutched in her hand.

She couldn't digest what had happened, couldn't believe she survived it, couldn't believe it really happened as if he had stepped into a scene from one of the books she read that turned into reality in an instant.
Slowly, carefully, still a bit dizzy, she tiptoned between the glass shards beside his sprawled body and exited from behind the bar.
With shaky steps, she walked to the reception counter.
And just as she was reaching for the phone receiver, the door next to her was pushed open, and the big and good Yoski stood in the doorway.
She stared at him in amazement.
The receiver dropped from her hand, and without realizing it, her limbs collapsed and she fell at his feet with heartbreaking sobs.
Not crying, just whimpering.
She doesn't remember how he got her back on her feet, hardly seated or gently laid her on the armchair while she trembled and whimpered.
It was enough for him to look at her torn shirt to understand that something bad had happened.
He approached the bar to bring her a glass of water and almost stumbled over the feet of the guy lying there unconscious.
A sharp smell of whiskey filled his nostrils, and only then did he notice the shattered bottle pieces.
He handed her the glass of water, bent over her, and gently asked, What happened?
Who is this guy?
I don't know, she whispered.
I immediately knew he was trouble.
In my heart, I prayed that you or Danny would walk in at any moment.
It didn't happen.
He was totally out of it, completely crazed.
I was sure it was over for me.
I don't know how I managed to reach the bottle and smash it on his head before he did anything further.
I can't shake his sour smell.
He examined her head.
He hit you in the face.
There's a big bruise near your eye and ear.
Does it hurt?
She stared at him.
I don't know.
I still don't really feel anything, still completely in shock.
Yoski got up, went to the phone and called the police, explaining that there was an attempted assault and the attacker was unconscious.
They should come and also call an ambulance.
It was Moshe the dispatcher on the phone.
He wanted to know you're okay.
It's insane how everyone knows.
each other in this town.
Anyway, they're on their way.
Suddenly, he looked at her seriously and said, Look, maybe we should think about how from now on you behave a bit less freely and trust a bit less whoever walks in.
You're here many hours alone.
It's quite surprising this hasn't happened until now.
There's no shortage of lunatics.
We'll need to figure something out.
She sank deeper into the armchair, aware that only now her breath was returning to normal, and she was starting to recover.

She weighed heavily on what he said, understanding he was right, but refusing to start behaving out of fear, just knowing it would take time until she could enter behind the bar with the same natural confidence she had before.
She'd have to let time do its thing until the damage from those cursed moments healed.

After the police left and the rusty man was taken by ambulance for stitches in his head before being arrested, Leora got up to clean the floor of glass shards, washing it again and again with plenty of water and soap to cleanse the spilled whiskey.
Yoski wanted to help her, but she refused.
You just sit on the chair and don't step on the wet.
That'll help the most.
I just want to wash away all traces of the madness that happened here.
When she finished, she leaned on the mop handle, raised her eyes to Yoski, forcing herself to smile a small and brave smile, and told him, tell me, couldn't you have come a few minutes earlier?
At night she couldn't sleep.

She tossed and turned, trying to chase away the thoughts and images that flashed through her mind and reminded her of the moments of fear, hugging her pillow tight, at times even placing it over her head, hoping maybe the darkness and complete silence would bring sleep.
But nothing worked.
Something in her refused to calm down, still on alert at any sound or bad wind that might come.
She would have to tell Yosef what happened.
After all, he'd hear it from someone sooner or later.
For a moment, she thought maybe something good would come of it, and he'd start spending more time at home.
Again and again, the rusty man appeared before her eyes.
She could almost smell his sour scent, shaking her head to erase the image, then recalling the words Yoski told her before she went to her room.
You were a hero, just a hero.
Now go and sleep well and dream only sweet dreams.
You hear?
And remember, I'm here looking out for you just a few rooms away.
The big and good Yoski took charge.
It didn't exactly succeed.
From time to time, she glanced at the watch on her wrist.
The small watch with the blue strap she received from mom for her bat mitzvah, along with the human comedy by Soroyan in English.
truly a human comedy with everything that's happening to me," she thought.
At three in the morning, she surrendered, turned on the light beside her bed, reached under the bed, and grabbed Atlas Shrugged, which had been lying there for days.
In a second, she was in another world, forgetting everything.
Large parts of this book were so devoid of logic, they swept her into a different, other world, filled with extreme elements of anger and power.
But even Ein Rand, who challenges at the gates, sometimes had a soft and wonderful sentence that went straight to her heart.
For a few moments, as long as the music lasts, you can completely give in, forget everything, and just allow yourself to feel.
And in her heart, she was already with her melodies, soothing and comforting.
Without realizing it, her eyes closed.
The heavy book fell by her side, and she sank into a deep, dreamless sleep that temporarily erased the rusty man, his sour smell, and the fears he left behind.
